title: 110_s297
content: The "Business Relief and Incentives for Small Entrepreneurs Act of 2007" or the "Business RAISE Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes a provision for 15-year straight-line cost recovery for certain improvements to retail space and qualified new restaurant improvements. The "Business RAISE Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a 15-year recovery period for qualified retail improvement property placed in service before January 1, 2008. This applies to nonresidential building improvements. The "Business RAISE Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a 15-year recovery period for qualified retail improvement property in nonresidential buildings open to the public for selling goods or services. Excluded improvements are those related to building enlargement, elevators, escalators, or internal structural framework. The amendment adds a 15-year recovery period for qualified retail improvement property in nonresidential buildings, excluding improvements related to building enlargement, elevators, escalators, or internal structural framework. The amendment adds a 15-year recovery period for qualified retail improvement property in nonresidential buildings. The amendments in this section apply to qualified retail improvement property placed in service after the enactment date. Qualified restaurant property is redefined as a building with over 50% of square footage dedicated to meal preparation and on-premises consumption. The amendment made by this subsection applies to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. The Work Opportunity Tax Credit is addressed in Section 3 of the Act. Expansion of eligibility to all disabled veterans under Section 51(d)(3)(A) includes certification requirements and a disability rating of at least 10 percent under section 1155 of title 38, United States Code. The Secretary of Labor is tasked with publicizing and administering the expanded work opportunity tax credit, providing assistance to employers, and authorizing appropriations for these purposes. Authorization of appropriations of $2,500,000 annually for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to the Secretary of Labor for implementing the amendments. The effective date applies to individuals starting work for employers after the enactment of the Act.
